118744 S0926-860X(22)00267-8 10.1016/j.apcata.2022.118744 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 γ-valerolactone (GVL) selectivity as a function of support/co-catalyst (a) surface acidity, (b) B/L (ratio) where B: Brønsted and L: Lewis acid sites, (c) M + S W (ratio) where T: total, W: weak, M: medium, S: strong acid sites and (d) hammett acidity (-H 0) upon hydrocyclization of aqueous levulinic acid. Conditions: 90 °C, 10 bar initial H2, 600 rpm, selectivity at 30–50% conversion. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) initial rate vs. support acidity (all catalysts), (b) initial rate vs. support acidity (bifunctional catalysts), (c) γ-valerolactone (GVL) selectivity vs. initial rate and, (d) initial rate vs. 4-hydroxypentanoic acid/ γ-valerolactone (HPA/GVL) ratio. Conditions: 90 °C, 10 bar initial H2, 600 rpm. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Summary of catalytic performance under continuous flow (a) effect of catalyst (illustrated at 10 bar, 5 ml/min H2, 4.5 h−1 WHSV, *7.5 h−1 WHSV), (b) effect of WHSV (illustrated for Ru/20%NbSBA-15 at 90 °C, 10 bar), (c) effect of reaction temperature (illustrated for Ru/20%NbSBA-15 at 4.5 h−1 WHSV), (d) levulinic acid conversion as function of time on stream (illustrated at 10 bar, 5 ml/min H2, 7.5 h−1 WHSV, *2.5 h−1 WHSV) (WHSV is defined as gfeed/gcath−1). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Catalytic performance of Ru/20%NbSBA-15 catalyst (2.5 wt% Ru) upon continuous hydrogenation of 5 wt% aqueous levulinic acid during 12 days time on stream under varying reaction conditions (WHSV is defined as gfeed/gcath−1). (Note-lines are to aid visualization only). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Catalytic performance of Ru/50%NbSi-COMp catalyst (2.5 wt% Ru) upon continuous hydrogenation of 5 wt% aqueous levulinic acid during 7 days time on stream under varying reaction conditions (WHSV is defined as gfeed/gcath−1). Inorganic Materials and Catalysis Division, CSIR-Central Salt and Marine Chemicals Research Institute (CSIR-CSMCRI), Council of Scientific & Industrial Research (CSIR) G. B. Marg Bhavnagar Gujarat 364002 India Herein, we demonstrate that surface acid-base properties have marked effect upon the performance (activity, selectivity and stability) of supported Ru catalysts upon tandem hydrocyclization (hydrogenation-dehydration) of aqueous levulinic acid. A mesoporous bi-functional Ru/NbOPO4/SBA-15 catalyst incorporating highly dispersed Ru sites and well balanced strong Brønsted acidic sites (optimum B/L and M+S/W ratio) was identified, which outperformed the benchmark monofuncational (Ru/SBA-15, Ru/MCM-41) and physically blended bi-functional catalysts (Ru catalysts mixed with acid co-catalysts e.g. NbOPO4/Amberlyst-15). Further, the catalyst also demonstrated remarkable stability in a fixed-bed reactor, maintaining steady activity and γ-valerolactone selectivity (72–86%) during ca. 300 h time on stream (10 bar, 90–100 °C), corroborating its industrial potential. The exceptional performance and durability of the bi-functional catalyst was attributed to the presence of well dispersed hydrothermally and chemically stable acid (NbOPO4) and redox (Ru) sites. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Tandem hydrocyclization γ-valerolactone Supported Ru-catalysts Bi-functional catalyst Flow chemistry Catalyst deactivation 1 Introduction In the search towards sustainable future, the concept of bio-refining and conversion of biomass into high value products (fuels, chemicals and materials) has gained considerable importance. Levulinic acid (LA) is a well-known product of hexose sugar hydrolysis/dehydration and is inexpensively obtained by the decomposition of cellulosic feedstocks. Levulinic acid is an attractive platform material for the production of range of chemical products, including methyltetrahydrofuran, γ-valerolactone, 1,4-propanediol, angelicalactone, diphenolic acid and levulinate esters. Among the various levulinic acid derivatives, γ- valerolactone, in particular, is of significant commercial importance, owing to its usefulness as a solvent, food additive, fuel component, and as a precursor for high value chemicals (linear α-olefins, esters) and fuel range synthetic hydrocarbons [1,2]. Traditionally, γ-valerolactone has been obtained via hydrogenation of levulinic acid under pressurized H2 (1–5 MPa), followed by intramolecular dehydration of the 4-hydroxypentanoic acid intermediate, at elevated temperatures. Alternatively, levulinic acid dehydrates to produce angelica lactones which undergo subsequent hydrogenation to produce γ-valerolactone ( Scheme 1). γ-valerolactone has also been produced from furfuryl alcohol (hydration hydrogenation), furfural (hydrogenation hydration hydrogenation), glucose as well as cellulosic feedstocks using multifunctional catalysts [3]. The catalytic conversion of levulinic acid or its derivatives have been demonstrated with both homogeneous and heterogeneous noble, non-noble metal and bimetallic catalysts whereupon both catalyst and nature of solvent/reaction media has marked effect on catalysts activity and selectivity [3–16]. In addition to the traditional hydrogenation, catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone has also been extensively studied with secondary alcohol (2-propanol) or formic acid as hydrogen source (hydrogen donor), the reaction can be catalyzed by supported metal or non-noble metalphosphides/phosphates, noble metal as well as Lewis acidic catalysts. Nevertheless, due to requirement of high purity feed, longer reaction/residence time, harsh process conditions, catalyst deactivation and issues related to laborious product separation, hydrogen donor regeneration and reactor corrosion (in case of formic acid) the utility of CTH for sustainable γ-valerolactone production is limited [1,3,14,15]. Nevertheless based on the literature data, Ru appears to be the most active and selective metal, owing to its unique ability to selectively hydrogenate carbonyl groups particularly in water, as such Ru based materials represent the most versatile catalytic systems for valorization of industrial grade aqueous levulinic acid [1,2,14,17–19]. However, the commercial usefulness of Ru based catalysts have been limited due to deactivation issues resulting from (a) the leaching of Ru species through the formation of Ru–carboxylate complexes with levulinic acid (pKa ~4.59) in liquid phase (especially in water), (b) deposition of carbonaceous impurities (particularly in non aqueous solvents) and (c) sintering and coking of Ru-nanoparticles in vapor phase reactions. Another drawback of processes operating at under high H2 pressure and elevated reaction temperatures is the reduced γ-valerolactone selectivity due to the formation of over-hydrogenation by-products such as 2-methyltetrahydrofuran and pentane-1,4-diol (Scheme 1) [17,20–22]. The hydrogenation of levulinic acid (particularly in aqueous phase) to 4-hydroxypentanoic acid has been shown to be kinetically favorable at low temperatures (activation barrier of 48 kJ mol–1), relative to the dehydration/cyclization/esterification of 4-hydroxypentanoic acid to γ-valerolactone (activation barrier of 70 kJ mol–1), while the latter dehydration step was shown to be accelerated either by (a) elevating the reaction temperature (≥150 °C) or by (b) introducing an acid as a co-catalyst or promoter (Scheme 1) [12,17,23]. In fact, in view of the benefits of low temperature operations (low-energy consumption and minimization of sintering and coking of Ru nanoparticles), increased diffusional limitations at elevated temperatures, and the possibility of utilizing industrial grade aqueous levulinic acid as starting material, both mineral Brønsted acids and solid Brønsted acids (Amberlyst-15, Amberlyst-70, niobic acid etc.) have been employed as co-catalysts for direct hydrogenation/hydrocyclization of levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone under mild conditions [6,24–27]. For example, upon levulinic acid hydrogenation at 50 °C and 40.1 bar, Bond et al. reported ca. 18 fold increase in γ-valerolactone selectivity (88 vs. 5) for a stacked bed reactor comprising Ru/C (bed 1) and Amberlyst-15 (bed 2) as opposed to a single bed reactor comprising Ru/C [23]. On the other hand, use of mineral acids (particularly H2SO4) should be avoided as many studies have identified them as poisons for Ru catalysts especially under H2 rich environments. In recent years, attempts have also been made towards the synthesis and application of bi-functional Ru catalysts for hydrocyclization of levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone, such as those based on inexpensive sulfonic resins (DOWEX, Amberlyst-15), SO3H acid functionalized carbons, graphene, graphene-oxide and metal organic frameworks as supports [17,28,29]. Although, good to excellent catalytic performances have been obtained over the graphene, and metal organic framework based bi-functional Ru catalysts in batch mode, such catalysts cannot be considered practical from the point of industrial utility due to the high costs and limited material availability. Other, drawbacks of carbon, MOF and polymer based catalytic materials include strong adsorption of reagents and leaching which often lead to loss of activity upon prolonged use (fouling, leaching) and the requirement of complicated regeneration procedures needed to reactivate catalyst. Moreover, the stability of such catalysts are yet to be proven under intensified process conditions, such as those used in continuous fixed-bed reactors [4,27,30–32]. Besides, in many instances, sulfated supports such as sulfonated graphene and, sulfonated mesoporous carbons have been shown to in fact, inhibit the activity of Ru-catalysts upon hydrogenation reactions, resulting from the formation of sulfides and/or metal sulfides with Ru, under the strongly reducing reaction conditions or the pretreatment conditions typically needed to activate the catalysts [25]. Therefore, extreme care needs to be taken during the catalyst synthesis/activation step, to prevent the reduction of surface SO3H sites, and also to prevent permanent poisoning/loss of Ru phase by the formation of metal sulfides [33–35]. In fact, the deactivation of SO3H groups and Ru metal under reducing conditions or under hydrogen atmosphere is well documented in literature, which limits the practical utility of bi-functional metal catalysts containing acidic SO3H sites/groups for application within hydrogenation/hydrocyclization/hdroesterification/hydrodeoxygenation chemistry [34,36]. Hence, the development of practical, efficient and stable bi-functional Ru catalysts by incorporating chemically non-reducible and hydrothermally stable Brønsted acid sites for selective low temperature hydrocyclization of aqueous levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone has remained a major technical challenge. Recently, in many industrially important reactions (such as oxidation, deoxygenation and hydrogenolysis), direct correlation could be established between the surface acid-base properties of the carriers (supports) with the activity, selectivity and stability of metal (e.g. Au, Pd, Ru) supported catalysts. In addition, the nature of surface defects, on carriers have also been shown to influence the stability, dispersion and particle size of supported metal nanoparticles [37–43]. In the view of the points disused above, the aim of the present work is to develop an active, selective and stable catalyst for continuous hydrocyclization of aqueous levulinic acid γ-valerolactone under low temperature conditions (≤100 °C). Thus within this work we have explored catalytic performance various bi-functional SiO2 (SBA-15 and MCM-41) catalysts, incorporating supported Nb (Nb2O5 and NbOPO4) particles as acid sites and Ru nanoparticles as redox sites and evaluated their performance with respect to benchmark Ru catalysts (monofunctional and bi-functional). Further, considering the importance of support acid-base properties upon catalyst performance, we also critically explored the role of catalyst redox (dispersion, loading) and acid-base properties (e.g. acidity, acidic strength, B/L ratio) upon the activity, selectivity and stability of catalytic materials. Most importantly, herein we corroborate the potential industrial feasibility of a bi-functional SBA-15 catalyst incorporating small amounts of immobilized Ru (2.5 wt%) and NbOPO4 particles (10–20 wt%) for continuous γ-valerolactone production from aqueous levulinic acid, from extended stability tests conducted in a fixed-bed reactor under industrially relevant conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of hydrogenation catalysts All reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Unless specified the hydrogenation catalysts were obtained by the incipient wetness impregnation method using ruthenium (III) trichloride hydrate (pure, 38–40% Ru, SRL) as the metal precursor. The nominal metal loading was fixed at 2.5 wt% for all catalysts. All catalysts were pre-reduced in a stream of pure H2 at 400 °C or NaBH4 at room temperature prior to use. The detailed synthetic procedures adapted for the synthesis of individual catalysts as well as the catalyst supports are summarized in supporting information. 2.2 Characterization The catalytic materials and, the supports were extensively characterized to evaluate their chemical composition, surface, textural, acid-base, structural and, morphological properties. The surface acidity of the supports and, catalytic materials were determined by NH3 temperature programmed desorption (TPD) and pyridine FT-IR. H2 uptake, metal area, metal particle dispersion and metal particle size were determined by H2 pulse chemisorption. Specific surface area, pore size and pore volumes were obtained from N2-physisorption measurements. Structure, morphology and microstructure of catalytic materials were investigated by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Surface elemental compositions were investigated by energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy (EDX) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Thermal stability of the catalytic materials was studied by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under inert atmosphere. Spent catalysts were also analogously characterized to evaluate the various compositional, morphological or textural changes occurring in the material during the catalytic application. The specific details of the different analytical procedures employed for the characterization of catalysts and, catalytic supports are given in supporting information. 2.3 Catalytic reaction procedures Aqueous phase hydrogenation of levulinic acid was carried out under batch as well as, continuous flow conditions at 10 bar H2 pressure. In all experiments free flowing catalyst particles sized between 50 and 150 µm were used. In a typical batch experiment, after the reactor (~13 ml) was charged with the desired amount of catalyst (0.57 mol% Ru with respect to levulinic acid, particle size 50–100 µm) and feed (0.25 g levulinic acid in 5 g water), the reactor was sealed and purged up to 5 times with pure H2 gas (99.95%). Next, the reactor was pressurized to the desired initial H2 pressure (10 bar) and the reaction initiated by heating it to the desired reaction temperature under stirring (magnetic). In a typical flow experiment, the dry catalyst (350–400 mg, 100–150 µm) was packed into a fixed-bed micro reactor (1/4 in. OD, 4.35 mm ID and length 7 cm, 1.04 ml) supported on each side by two 2 µm SS316 frits. Next reactor was heated to the desired reaction temperature (85–100 °C) using aluminum heating blocks heated by band heaters. The liquid feed comprising aqueous levulinic acid (50 g/L) was pumped continuously into the reactor using an HPLC pump (SSI Series II), while H2 was simultaneously supplied using a mass flow controller (Brooks Instrument). The system pressure was maintained at 10 bar using an Equilibar U3L series precision back pressure regulator. The detailed description of the custom made micro batch reactor and the continuous flow fixed-bed micro reactor and relevant experimental conditions are given in supporting information (Fig. S1). For quantification, reaction products were immediately analyzed by HPLC and 1H NMR after passing the collected products through (0.25 µm syringe filters) (delay >24 h between sampling and analysis caused significant overestimation of γ-valerolactone due to the autocatalytic cyclization of 4-hydroxypentanoic acid to γ-valerolactone). HPLC quantifications were based on calibration curves obtained with standard compounds. The conversion (X), yield (Y) and selectivity (S) are defined as follows: (1) X % = 1 − C t C 0 × 100 % (2) Y % = C product C 0 × 100 % (3) S % = C product C 0 − C t × 100 % where, c o and c t represent the initial and final concentration of levulinic acid (reactant) and c product denotes the concentration of the product (γ-valerolactone, 4-hydroxypentanoic acid or any other product) formed. The specific reaction rate (r) and turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated at ≤ 30% conversion as: (4) r = mol LAconsumed mol Ru × time × 100 % (5) TOF = mol LAconsumed mol Ru × time × Dispersion × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic material characterization In this work, we prepared a series of Ru-catalyst using supports of varying surface acid-base properties. Table 1 presents a summary of the textural and surface acid-base properties of the different support materials such as mesoporous silicas (SBA-15 and MCM-41), nitrogen doped activated carbon (NAC), NbOPO4 modified mesoporous silicas (10%NbMCM-41, 10%NbSBA-15% and 20%NbSBA-15), mNb2O5, mNbOPO4, NbSi-COMp (NbOPO4-SiO2 composite) and Nb2O5used in the work. From the data presented in Table 1, it is seen that mNbOPO4 presented the highest amount of surface acidity followed by NbSi-COMp and NbOPO4 modified/supported ordered silica materials (10%NbMCM-41, 10%NbSBA-15% and 20%NbSBA-15), while commercial Nb2O5, NAC and unmodified ordered mesoporous silica materials were the least acidic. In particular, these materials did not incorporate any medium or strong acid sites and presented low B/L and ( M + S ) W ratio. Furthermore, with the exception of mNb2O5 and mNbOPO4 all supports presented a highly porous morphology/structure with large specific surface areas and well defined, small mesopores (average pore diameter 2.9–9.39 nm) (Table 1). Table 2, summarizes the textural and metal particle properties (average metal particle size, metal area and, dispersion) of various supported Ru-catalysts obtained from the different supports discussed above. From the data presented in Table 2, the importance of the support surface chemistry on metal particle dispersion and average metal particle size is clearly seen. The presence of N-doping as well as strongly acidic surface functional groups was clearly favorable for the formation of small and well dispersed (Ru) nanoparticles, which could be attributed to the presence of ‘charge-transfer stabilization’ (CTS) and ‘strong metal–support interaction’ (SMSI) effects, respectively similar to the trends observed in literature [38,41,44,45]. The SMSI effect was clearly more advantageous when compared to CTS, as highlighted by the formation of highly dispersed (16.3–32.8%) and small Ru nanoparticles (4.06–8.1 nm) over NbOPO4 based catalysts (Table 2). The presence of well dispersed Ru species and the uniform distribution of surface acidic groups (immobilized Nb2O5/NbOPO4) sites in the bi-metallic could also be confirmed from EDX microelement (Ru, P, O, and Nb) mapping images of Ru/20%NbSBA-15 (Fig. S2, supporting information). The electron images and N2-physisorption data also revealed that upon Ru and NbOPO4 modification the material could retain the characteristic SBA-15 morphology and textural properties (Table 2) [21]. Further, from the representative NH3-TPD plots presented in Fig. S3 (supporting information), the positive effect of Ru nanoparticle immobilization upon catalyst surface acidity is also clearly observed. The enhanced acidity of Ru-loaded samples in comparison to the unmodified SBA-15 or NAC could be attributed to the presence of Lewis acidic RuO2 and/or RuOx as well as residual RuCl3 species [37,40]. In fact, similar combination of Ru/RuOx nanoparticles loaded on carbon supports have been previously employed as a bi-functional catalyst for glycerol hydrogenolysis, acetylene hydrochlorination and furfural hydrodeoxygenation [37,39,40]. In another related work, Srinivasan and co-workers utilized a partially reduced hydrous ruthenium oxide catalyst incorporating metallic Ru sites supported on RuO2·xH2O as an effective catalyst upon γ-valerolactone production from aqueous levulinic acid, whereupon acidic RuOx was proposed to aid in the ring closure step [2]. However, such catalytic systems are not expected to be stable under the reducing reaction environment, in particular under the intensified operational conditions of a flow/fixed-bed reactor as the acidic RuO2.xH2O phase is expected to slowly reduce to the metallic Ru(0) which will result in gradual loss of surface acidity and expected to cause a steady increase in 4-hydroxypentanoic acid selectivity (this phenomena was indeed verified on a Ru/RuOx/SBA-15 catalysts from extended experiments conducted under continuous flow, see below). Furthermore, it also worth noting that in the bulk of literature, including the above cited work γ-valerolactone selectivity/product distribution has been reported on the basis HPLC/GC analysis, which results in significant overestimation of γ-valerolactone, as the unstable intermediate 4-hydroxypentanoic acid (or γ-hydroxyvaleric acid) readily cyclizes in the presence of acidic mobile phase of HPLC or high temperature conditions of GC analysis [1,2,14,17–19]. In fact, Piskun and co-workers recently showed the cyclization of 4-hydroxypentanoic acid to γ-valerolactone in aqueous media to be an autocatalytic, which readily takes place even under ambient conditions (until equilibrium is reached between γ-valerolactone/4-hydroxypentanoic acid, typically requiring 6–8 days at 25 °C). Thus, while accessing the catalyst performance, considerable care needs to be taken upon analysis of the reaction mixtures from hydrocyclization of aqueous levulinic acid and minimize the effect of secondary factors (thermal, autocatalysis and mobile-phase) promoting 4-hydroxypentanoic acid ring closure. In fact in this work also, analysis of reaction mixtures with either GC-FID or HPLC gave significant overestimation of GVL selectivity (99%). Therefore, we opted for a combined HPLC and 1H NMR based analytical approach to access the composition of reaction products (for details, refer to the supporting information, Fig. S4) [32,46]. 3.2 Catalytic activity 3.2.1 Batch screening and effect of surface acidity In order to evaluate the influence of catalyst textural and acid-base properties upon hydrogenation of aqueous levulinic acid, preliminary catalytic tests were conducted in batch mode at 90 °C and 10 bar initial H2 pressure. The results from batch experiments presented in Table 3, confirm the influence of catalyst properties upon levulinic acid hydrogenation. Further, comparison of the normalized reaction rates (r), TOF and γ-valerolactone selectivity revealed importance the role of surface acidic and textural properties; whereupon catalysts presenting optimum balance of surface acidity and a high porosity presented the highest performance (viz. Ru/10%NbSBA-15, Ru/20%NbSBA-15 and Ru/50%NbSi-COMp) in terms of activity and desired product selectivity (Table 3). Although, monofuncational Ru/SBA-15 presented the highest TOF (1850 h−1), it presented a low γ-valerolactone selectivity (47%) which could be attributed to lack of acidic sites. In fact, plots of γ-valerolactone selectivity vs. catalyst acidic properties (i.e. catalyst surface acidity and B/L (ratio), M + S W (ratio) and acidic strength vs. γ-valerolactone selectivity) revealed a positive co-reaction, in agreement with the catalytic role of strong acid sites upon the intramolecular esterification/dehydration/cyclization of 4-hydroxypentanoic acid intermediate ( Scheme 2). The effect was more noticeable at lower temperature 70 °C, as the contribution from thermal reaction was significantly minimized under such conditions ( Fig. 1(a-b)). In particular the positive co-relation observed between B/L (ratio) and M + S W (ratio) with γ-valerolactone selectivity was clearly suggestive of the important role strong Brønsted acidic sites upon the esterification step during hydrocyclization of aqueous levulinic acid at low temperatures (Fig. 1(c)). The plots of acid strength (-H 0) vs. γ-valerolactone selectivity also reveal a positive co-relation, consistent with the increased cyclization/dehydration rates over strongly acidic catalysts (Fig. 1(d)). Most importantly, the selectivity trends (90–93%) obtained with the large pore bi-functional catalyst incorporating supported Ru nanoparticles and Bronsted acidic NbOPO4 particles viz. Ru/10%NbSBA-15, Ru/20%NbSBA-15, Ru/50%NbSi-COMp were comparable with the selectivity trends (92–96%) observed with the Ru supported on mesoporous NbOPO4 (Ru/mNbOPO4) and physically blended (mixed) bi-functional catalytic systems comprising of supported Ru/SBA-15 or Ru/N-doped carbon (NAC) with solid Brønsted acid promoters (i.e. NbOPO4 or Amberlyst-15). In, contrast, the Ru catalysts based on basic, weakly acidic and/or neutral supports such as N-doped carbon (NAC), Na-beta and mesoporous silica (SBA-15 and MCM-41) presented the lowest γ-valerolactone selectivity (47–61%) under identical conditions. Further, from the data presented in Table 3, significant variation could be seen in terms of levulinic acid conversion and normalized reaction rates/TOF for the compared catalysts, with the catalysts presenting higher γ-valerolactone selectivity generally presenting a lower levulinic acid conversion and normalized rates/TOF. To further evaluate the role of catalyst acid-base properties upon activity and selectivity, initial rates (mmolLAconsumedmin−1) were measured and plotted as function of support surface acidity, γ-valerolactone selectivity and 4-hydroxypentanoic acid/γ-valerolactone (HPA/GVL) ratio ( Fig. 2(a-d)). From the plots of initial rate vs. acidity and initial rate vs. γ-valerolactone selectivity a negative co-relation could be observed, which clearly indicated the adverse effect of too many acidic sites upon hydrogenation of aqueous levulinic acid (Fig. 2(a-c)). In fact, the catalytic materials presenting the highest concentration acidic sites i.e. physical mixtures of Ru/SBA-15 or Ru/NAC with solid Brønsted acids (Amberlyst-15 and mNbOPO4), presented the poorest activity (initial hydrogenation rate), while in terms of desired product (γ-valerolactone) selectivity these catalysts were the most superior, Fig. 2(a). Our findings are consistent with the findings of Serio and co-workers also reporting reduced hydrogenation activity of bi-functional Ru-Nb-Si catalysts in comparison to a Ru-Si catalyst [47]. Interestingly, a careful comparison of activity vs. selectivity plots of bi-functional catalysts indicated the existence of a synergistic influence of acid and metal sites upon the reaction Fig. 2(c). Indeed, a volcano type behavior was observed when the initial rate was plotted as a function of support surface acidity for the bi-functional catalysts incorporating both metal (Ru) and acid sites, with the Ru/20%NbSBA-15 and catalyst presenting good activity and high γ-valerolactone selectivity, Fig. 2(b) and Table 3. In fact, the TOF (hydrogenation activity) of Ru/20%NbSBA-15 (1712 h−1) was en par with the most active hydrogenation catalyst Ru/SBA-15 (1850 h−1), while simultaneously affording a high γ-valerolactone selectivity of 93% (Table 3). Overall, the observed activity and selectivity trends are consistent with combined influence of acid-base, metal particle and textural properties upon catalyst performance (Table 1, Table 2 and Table 3). Most importantly, the SBA-15 based bi-functional materials reported herein exhibited superior catalytic performance (superior hydrogenation as well as cyclization/dehydration activity) when compared to the Ru-Nb-Si catalysts reported in literature, the improved performance could be attributed to presence of well dispersed Ru sites and well balanced strong NbOPO4 sites [47]. Further, the cyclization/esterification of 4-hydroxypentanoic acid to γ-valerolactone has been shown to be an equilibrium reaction with an equilibrium constant (K = [γ-valerolactone]/[4-hydroxypentanoic acid]), where 1/K is expected to be a function of the ratio of [rate of hydrogenation]/[the rate of intramolecular esterification]. Therefore, under the circumstances of rate of intramolecular esterification being dependent only on bulk acidity of the solution and not by acidity of the catalyst surface, 1/K can be expected to be a linear function of the initial reaction rate (i.e. hydrogenation rate), with higher initial (hydrogenation) rates typically leading to higher [4-hydroxypentanoic acid]/[γ-valerolactone] [48]. However, in this study plots of initial rate vs. [4-hydroxypentanoic acid]/[γ-valerolactone] ratio did not show any co-relation further supporting the role of catalyst/support surface acidity upon the cyclization of 4-hydroxypentanoic acid (Fig. 2(d) and Scheme 2). Overall our results are in stark contrast with the findings of Piskun et al. reporting 4-hydroxypentanoic acid cyclization to be independent of support acidity under comparable conditions. Even so, it is to be emphasized here in their work supports presenting only medium-weak acidity have been compared by Piskun et al., while in the current work we have evaluated a broader range of catalyst supports presenting basic, weak, medium as well as strong Brønsted acidic sites [48]. In addition, experiments were also conducted with Ru supported SBA-15 catalysts obtained by different deposition techniques (viz. Ru/SBA-15-NaOH, Ru/SBA-15-H2O2 and Ru-SBA-15-IW-H2) to evaluate the influence of synthetic conditions on activity and selectivity as synthetic conditions are known to have a marked effect on surface acidity (it directly effects the oxidation state of Ru i.e. Ru/RuOx ratio) [40]. Indeed from, the plots presented in Fig. S3a (supporting information), it is clearly seen that the catalysts obtained by oxidation (H2O2) deposition presented the highest GVL selectivity as it presented the highest surface acidity. The origin of acidity on the Ru modified catalysts could be explained by the Lewis acidity of unreduced RuO2/RuOx phase as illustrated in the representative NH3-TPD plots (Fig. S3b, supporting information) [37,39,40]. It is also important to highlight here that in all batch experiments only stoichiometric amount of H2 (ca. 4 bar) was being consumed producing 4-hydroxypentanoic acid and γ-valerolactone as the exclusive products (Fig. S4, supporting information). This finding was consistent with the selective hydrogenation of ketonic group of aqueous levulinic acid under mild reaction conditions [17,24,33,34]. Albeit upon reuse, all catalysts presented identical performances in terms of initial rates (data not shown); we observed considerable difference in terms of the stability of metal as well as acidic phases of the evaluated catalysts (ICP-MS) (Table 3). The Ru catalysts based on un-modified silica supports (Ru/SBA-15 and Ru/MCM-41), weakly acidic zeolite (Na-beta) and basic N-doped carbon (Ru/NAC) presented the considerable Ru leaching (1–168 ppm). In contrast, the bi-functional Ru catalysts incorporating strongly Brønsted acidic Nb phase (Ru/10%NbMCM-41, Ru/10%NbSBA-15, Ru/20%NbSBA-15, Ru/50%NbSi-COMp, Ru/mNbOPO4 and Ru/mNb2O5) presented negligible Ru leaching (0–0.3 ppm) under identical conditions (Table 3). The superior stability of Ru nanoparticles on acidic and N-doped carbon supports could be attributed to the presence strong metal support interactions; refer to the Ru dispersions in Table 2 [38,41,44,45,49,50]. Interestingly, the Ru/mNbOPO4 catalyst obtained by incipient wetness impregnation of RuCl3 on the highly Brønsted acidic and mesoporous NbOPO4 presented considerable leaching of phosphate species (190 ppm); similarly the Ru/50%NbSi-COMp composite catalyst with high Nb loading also presented considerable leaching of phosphate species (6.9 ppm). In contrast, phosphate leaching (0–1.2 ppm) was negligible for the supported catalysts incorporating a low loading of crystalline NbOPO4 particles in mesoporous silica carrier (Ru/10%NbMCM-41, Ru/10%NbSBA-15 and Ru/20%NbSBA-15). The improved stability of acidic sites in these catalysts could be attributed to the stabilization of NbOPO4 particles within the mesopores of the porous Si carriers. Furthermore, the origin of the difference in the stability of acidic phosphate sites in the two classes of materials could also be linked with the crystallinity of the NbOPO4 phases formed under the different synthetic conditions used. While the porous mNbOPO4 and 50%NbSi-COMp supports obtained by sol-gel/co-precipitation method under less acidic (dilute 2 M HCl) conditions presented an amorphous NbOPO4 phase, the 10%NbMCM-41, 10%NbSBA-15% and 20%NbSBA-15 materials obtained under concentrated HCl (12 M) conditions presented a well defined crystalline NbOPO4 phase (Fig. S5a, supporting information and Section 3.3 below), which might have contributed to the enhanced hydrothermal stability the later group of materials, as also reported in our earlier work [45]. The synthetic conditions also had a considerable effect on the acidic properties (strength and concentration), which in turn influenced the catalytic properties (Table 1 and Fig. S5b, supporting information). Interestingly no Nb leaching was observed in any of the Nb containing catalysts, an observation consistent with the excellent hydrothermal stability of oxides of niobium (Table 3) [45,47]. Overall, from our screening experiments in batch the positive impact of strongly acid sites in enhancing metal support interactions and catalyst performance is clearly evident. Most importantly a bi-functional (Ru/20%NbSBA-15) catalyst incorporating a mesoporous structure with optimum balance of strongly Brønsted acidic, crystalline NbOPO4 phase and highly dispersed Ru sites could be identified, which outperformed the various benchmark Ru catalysts simultaneously exhibiting a high hydrogenation as well as dehydration/cyclization activity under relatively mild conditions (Table 3) [47]. 3.2.2 Catalytic activity under continuous flow To further evaluate the catalytic performance of the synthesized bi-functional catalysts for continuous, low-temperature hydrocyclization of aqueous levulinic acid under industrially relevant experiments, performance of two representative catalyst (Ru/20%NbSBA-15 and Ru/50%NbSi-COMp) were further evaluated in comparison to the different benchmark catalysts (Ru/SBA-15, Ru/NAC and physical mixture of Ru/C+Amberlyst 15) in a fixed-bed reactor. Catalytic experiments were conducted in a custom-made lab scale up-flow fixed-bed reactor allowing for a concurrent flow of H2 gas and liquid feed (5 wt% aqueous levulinic acid) (Fig. S1, supporting information), keeping reaction conditions similar to those of batch operations. Fig. 3(a) summarizes the performance of bi-functional catalysts in comparison to the benchmark catalysts upon at hydrocyclization of aqueous levulinic acid 90 °C and 10 bar at constant weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 4.5 h−1. From data in Fig. 5 it is clear that among the tested catalyst only the bi-functional catalysts and Ru/C+Amberlyst-15 physical mixture could promote direct hydrocyclization of levulinic acid, affording a high γ-valerolactone selectivity (60–96%), while the two monofuncational catalysts (Ru/SBA-15 and Ru/NAC) produced hydrogenation product 4-hydroxypentanoic acid as the main product (selectivity 71–64%), confirming the role of acidic sites in expediting ring closure/dehydration reaction. Further, among the two bi-functional catalysts, Ru/20%NbSBA-15 presented ~1.3 fold higher γ-valerolactone selectively when compared to Ru/50%NbSi-COMp under identical reactions, the superior performance of the former could be attributed to presence of stronger Brønsted acid sites as indicated by its higher B/L (ratio) and M + S W (ratio) (Table 1). Overall, these findings were consistent with trends observed in batch mode and in agreement with catalytic role of strongly Brønsted acidic sites (-SO3H and NbOPO4) upon the cyclization of 4-hydroxypentanoic acid intermediate (Table 3). Fig. 3(b) presents the effect of reaction temperature and Fig. 3(c) the effect of WHSV on levulinic acid conversion and product selectivity for Ru/20%NbSBA-15. The data presented in Fig. 3(b) clearly shows the positive effect of reaction temperature, whereupon γ-valerolactone selectivity increases from 72% to 86% upon increasing the reaction temperature from 85 to 100 °C, the increased selectivity could be attributed to the increased esterification rates at elevated temperatures. Similarly, when WHSV was reduced from 7.5 to 3.1 at 90 °C, γ-valerolactone selectivity also increased and reached upto 82%, consentient with increased 4-hydroxypentanoic conversion upon increased residence time, and in good agreement with the trends already reported in literature establishing 4-hydroxypentanoic acid cyclization as the slowest/limiting step in direct hydrocyclization of levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone [23]. Further, the requirement of slightly elevated temperatures for ring closure with the NbOPO4 based materials (90–100 °C) in comparison to Amberlyst-15 (50–70 °C) could be attributed to the reduced acidic strength of the former (Hammett strength, H 0 −7 vs. −11) (Table 1) [36,45]. Interestingly, when compared to the results obtained in batch, the monofuncational catalyst presented a considerable reduction/loss in ring closure performance (ca. 50% loss in γ-valerolactone selectivity) while for bi-functional catalysts only 10–18% loss in γ-valerolactone selectivity was observed. The striking difference in γ-valerolactone in batch vs. flow operation could be mainly attributed to the absence of autocatalytic effects in case of former, due to the short residence times in the flow reactors (ca. 8–13 min in flow vs. 60–180 min in batch) which significantly minimized the rate of 4-hydroxypentanoic acid cyclization. Even so, the data obtained in flow experiments are consistent with trends in Fig. 1 and Fig. 2, and in strong agreement with the catalytic role of strongly acidic sites upon the ring closure reaction. The 72–86% γ-valerolactone selectivity observed with the bi-functional catalysts was also consistent with the slow rate of ring closure step, and comparable to the 88% selectivity reported for a stacked bed reactor comprising of Ru/C followed by Amberlyst-15 [23]. Fig. 3(d and e) presents levulinic acid conversion and as a function of time on stream for Ru/20%NbSBA-15 in comparison to the benchmark catalyst i.e. Ru/SBA-15, Ru/NAC and Ru/C+Amberlyst 15 catalyst at 90 °C (we opted to operate a high conversion regime to due to the rate limiting cyclization step). The data in Fig. 3(d) clearly show that although the four catalysts afforded a very high steady state conversion (98–84%), within 10 h the conversion dropped significantly for the bi-functional mixture (Ru/C+Amberlyst 15) while for monofunctional Ru/SBA-15 catalysts conversion initially increased and then followed a decreasing trend. In contrast the activity and selectivity of bi-functional Ru/20%NbSBA-15 and Ru/NAC remained unchanged. The first order deactivation rate coefficient of three catalysts in decreasing order being: Ru/C+Amberlyst 15 (0.044 h−1)> >Ru/SBA-15 (0.007 h−1)> >Ru/20%NbSBA-15 (0 h−1)=Ru/NAC (0 h−1). In terms, of desired product selectivity however Ru/C+Amberlyst-15 was the most superior followed by the bi-functional Ru/20%NbSBA-15, in agreement with role of acidic sites strength (Fig. 5(a)). The fast deactivation observed for Ru/C+Amberlyst 15 physical mixture could be attributed to several factors, which include sintering of Ru nanoparticles, loss of active Ru sites due to leaching and/or slow sulfidation of Ru species under the H2 and SO3H rich conditions as already reported by Villa et al. for Ru decorated sulfated carbon materials [34], while the slow deactivation of Ru/SBA-15 was mainly due to the continuous leaching of Ru particles (0.1 ppm, ICP-MS). In contrast, the high stability of Ru/NAC and Ru/20%NbSBA-15 catalyst could be attributed to the presence of strong metal support interactions which inhibited Ru particle sintering and leaching (at steady state Ru leaching was below detection limit of ICP-MS). It should however, be noted that due to the removal of weakly adsorbed Ru species, Ru leaching of 0.005–0.001 ppm was observed even for these stable catalysts during the initial stage (5 h) of reaction [38,41,44,45,49,50]. Finally, to further evaluate the lifetime/stability of the catalysts, samples from continuous experiments were continuously monitored at fixed conditions (fixed WHSV, H2 flow rate and fixed reaction temperature for at least 24 h or, until steady deactivation was observed). If no deactivation was observed during ~20–50 h operation, reaction parameters such as temperature, feed weight hourly space velocity, and H2 flow rate were adjusted to evaluate the effect of these parameters on the performance/stability of catalyst (see below). Interestingly, the extended time on stream data for the benchmark Ru/SBA-15 catalyst showed a unique deactivation behavior, with both γ-valerolactone selectivity and levulinic acid conversion showing a steady decline during ~65 h operation (Fig. S6, supporting information). While, the decreased activity could be mainly attributed to the slow, but continuous leaching of Ru (0.1 ppm ICP-MS), the decrease in γ-valerolactone selectivity and increased 4-hydroxypentanoic acid selectivity could be most likely attributed to the reduced dehydration/esterification rates, resulting from the loss of Lewis acidity due to the gradual reduction of acidic RuOx phase to metallic Ru(0) phase under the reducing reaction conditions (see below, spent catalyst characterization). In contrast, over the bi-functional Ru catalyst incorporating permanent, well balanced strong Brønsted acidity (NbOPO4 sites) (i.e. Ru/20%NbSBA-15), steady hydrogenation and cyclization/esterification activity could be maintained during extended operations ( Fig. 4). Among the two bi-functional catalysts Ru/20%NbSBA-15 and Ru/50%NbSi-COMp, the former obtained by post-synthetic modification of SBA-15 under acidic conditions (12 M HCl) was more advantageous in terms of both hydrogenation activity, dehydration activity (γ-valerolactone selectivity) as well as stability, similar to the trends observed in batch screening. The superior performance of Ru/20%NbSBA-15 could be mainly attributed to its unique combination acidic and textural properties i.e. ordered mesoporous structure with larger specific surface area and adequate amount of strong, Brønsted acid sites and negligible amount of weak acid sites; as reflected in the high B/L and M + S W ratio, which aided in the stabilization of Ru and NbOPO4 phase (Table 1 and Table 2). The trends in Fig. 4 was consistent with results of ICP-MS showing no evidence of Ru, Nb or phosphate species leaching after reaching steady state. In contrast, although the Ru/50%NbSi-COMp composite obtained by co-precipitation (in dil. 2 M HCl) with TEOS presented relatively higher Nb loading and total surface acidity, it presented a slightly reduced lower specific surface area, and a reduced acidic strength (lower B/L and M + S W ratio, Table 1 and Table 2) most likely due to presence of weakly bonded/physisorbed phosphate sites (Fig. S5b, supporting information) which resulted in the reduced dehydration/cyclization activity. Furthermore, the 50%NbSi-COMp presented ca. four-fold higher concentration of surface acid sites when compared to 20%NbSBA-15 material, which resulted in significant reduction of hydrogenation rate as also indicated in the batch results (in batch experiments hydrogenation rates were found to be negatively affected by surface acidity, Fig. 3 and Table 3). Overall, the hydrogenation activity and γ-valerolactone selectivity (dehydration/cyclization activity) trends observed in continuous flow experiments were in direct agreement with the trends observed in the batch experiments and consistent with role of acid sites as co-catalyst. Comparison of the time on stream data, for the two bi-functional catalysts further showed that the composite catalyst (Ru/50%NbSi-COMp) afforded a steady decline of γ-valerolactone selectivity when operating at 100 °C ( Fig. 4 & 5, supporting information) while conversion remained almost unaffected, the observed drop in desired product selectivity could be mainly attributed mainly to leaching of weakly bonded/physisorbed phosphate species (6.9 ppm, ICP-MS) in the composite material with an amorphous Si-NbOPO4 phase. In contrast, no phosphate leaching of was observed for the Ru/20%NbSBA-15 catalyst under steady state irrespective of reaction conditions, in agreement with the trends observed in batch and consistent with stability of crystalline NbOPO4 phase (see Section 3.2.1, Table 3). Interestingly, under the investigated reaction conditions no leaching of metal (Ru and Nb) was detected for either catalyst under steady state, confirming the improved hydrothermal stability of Nb based bi-functional catalysts. The difference in the stability of phosphate sites in the two materials could be explained in terms of the crystallinity of the NbOPO4 phases formed under the different synthetic conditions utilized. Overall, although the Ru/C+Amberlyst-15 physical mixture outperformed the bi-functional catalyst Ru/20%NbSBA-15 under steady state conditions, the later was clearly more advantageous in terms of long-term use (no change in conversion and selectivity during 300 h operation under varying reaction conditions) resulting from the enhanced stabilization of Ru-nanoparticles and the presence of permanent, stable (non-reducible and hydrothermally robust), strong and Brønsted acidic NbOPO4 phase (see spent catalyst characterization below). Although, a maximum γ-valerolactone selectivity of only 86% was achieved with the Ru/20%NbSBA-15 in a fixed-bed reactor, in theory selectivity could be further improved by adding a small segment of 20%NbSBA-15 downstream of the Ru/20%NbSBA-15 bed [23]. To better highlight the efficacy of developed catalysts the performance of developed bi-functional catalyst was further compared with the different Ru catalysts reported for continuous hydrogenation of levulinic acid in liquid phase ( Table 4). The data clearly shows that the activity, selectivity, productivity of developed bi-functional catalyst was on par with the segmented (Ru/C and Amberlyst-15) catalyst and bi-functional catalysts based on sulfated polymers (Ru@DOWEX), while in terms of stability Ru/20%NbSBA-15 was the most stable catalyst reported till date. Although, Ru/20%NbSBA-15 was inferior to the 0.5%Ru/C, 0.5%Ru/γ-Al2O3 and 1%Ru/TiO2 catalysts reported by Piskun et al. in terms productivity, the superior performance of aforementioned materials may be primarily attributed to use of 4.5 times higher H2 pressures (45 bar) (Table 4) [32]. 3.3 Used catalyst characterization Finally, to verify the experimentally observed activity, selectivity and stability of Ru/20%NbSBA-15 catalyst the used/spent catalyst collected from the fixed-bed reactor after 300 h time on stream was also extensively characterized which revealed no-evidence sintering, fouling, or major structural changes. The absence of Ru, Nb and P (phosphate) leaching was confirmed by ICP-MS analysis of collected liquid products at regular intervals. A comparison of the HR-TEM images of fresh and spent catalyst show that even after 300 h continuous operation under varying conditions of temperature, H2 and feed flow, aggregation or sintering of nanoparticles was non-observable ( Fig. 6). Similarly, comparison of powder XRD patterns (wide-angle) of the fresh and spent catalyst showed the existence of the crystalline NbOPO4 phase as characterized by the peaks at 2θ of 19.8° (110), 25.6° (101), 27.9° (200) 39.9° (220), 44.7° (310) and 47.9° (301), respectively. These findings are, consistent with the excellent hydrothermal and chemical stability of the acidic NbOPO4 phase of the developed bi-functional catalyst during continuous hydrocyclization of levulinic acid ( Fig. 7(a)) [21]. Comparison of the textural properties obtained from N2-physiorption confirmed that the catalytic material retained its mesoporous structure, 66% of its specific surface area and 74% of its pore volume even after prolonged use for ~300 h under varying experiential conditions. The slight reduction in porosity and specific surface area is most likely linked with the strongly chemisorbed high boiling oxygenated molecules on the spent catalyst surface (Fig. 7(b)). Comparison of the FT-IR patterns of fresh and spent Ru/20%NbSBA-15 showed the characteristic Si-O-Nb and Nb-O-P/P-OH vibrations at 585 and 633 cm−1 consistent with the presence of chemically bonded NbOPO4 phase and in agreement with the findings of XRD [21]. However, the spent Ru/20%NbSBA-15 exhibited two additional peaks at 1766 and 1738 cm−1 which could be attributed to the presence of chemisorbed organic species (γ-valerolactone or 4-hydroxypentanoic acid) (Fig. 7(c)). Further confirmation on the hypothesis regarding the presence of adsorbed organic species and the exceptional stability of acidic sites of Ru/20%NbSBA-15 catalyst, were obtained from the NH3-TPD analysis fresh and spent catalyst (Fig. 7(d)). The NH3-TPD patterns presented in Fig. 7(d) clearly show that the catalytic material retained the characteristic peaks corresponding to Nb2O5 and NbOPO4 phases around 150–180 °C and 300–350 °C. Although, an additional peak corresponding to the Lewis acidic RuOx phase could be observable around 220 °C for the fresh catalyst, the same disappeared for the catalyst recovered after 300 h time on stream. This change could be attributed to the reduction of RuOx phase to the metallic Ru phase under the reducing environment of reaction. In addition, for the spent catalyst an additional broad peak around 390 °C was observed, which could be attributed to the slow desorption of strongly chemisorbed organic species. The presence of chemisorbed organic molecules (fouling) upon the surface of spent catalyst was also supported by TGA data (Fig. 7(e)) and appearance of broad desorption peaks around 200 and 250 °C in TPD (blank) spectra of spent catalysts (Fig. S7, supporting information), corresponding to the boiling point of γ-Valerolactone (205 °C) and levulinic acid (245 °C). Comparison of the XPS spectra of spent Ru/20%NbSBA-15, with the as synthesized Ru/20%NbSBA-15 material, also revealed no major compositional changes upon the surface chemistry even after prolonged operations ( Fig. 8(a-c)). The only noticeable change was the shifting of Ru3d peak towards a lower binding energy value ~279.5 eV in the high resolution Ru3d spectra of spent catalyst (Fig. 8(b)). This observation was consistent with the slow reduction of unreduced RuOx species to metallic Ru and, in good agreement with the findings of NH3-TPD analysis. While the high resolution Nb3d peaks illustrated in Fig. 8(c) reveal the Nb3d5/2 binding energies to be 207.3 eV for both fresh and spent catalysts. Similarly, the P2p peak (not shown here) for both catalysts also shows the same binding energy (133.1 eV) for the P2p3/2 photoelectron lines. Also, XPS studies did not reveal no net decrease in the either Ru, Nb or P content (Fig. 8), in agreement with findings of ICP-OES analysis, while the increase in metallic Ru(0) content in the spent catalyst was attributed to the reduction of unreduced RuOx phase under reducing conditions of the reaction. The electron images of spent Ru/20%NbSBA-15 showed that the material retained its morphology even under harsh hydrothermal conditions, while EDX microelement (Ru, P, O, and Nb) mapping images confirmed the presence of well dispersed active metal (Ru) sites similar to the as synthesized catalyst (Fig. S6, supporting information). These experimental findings confirm that the connectivity of the phosphate species attached to Nb modified with mesoporous SiO2 (SBA-15) surface remained unaltered during 300 h time on stream thereby confirming the chemical robustness of the bi-functional Ru/20%NbSBA-15 catalyst upon aqueous phase hydrocyclization of levulinic acid. Most importantly, the strongly Brønsted acidic phosphate sites were non-reducible, even in the presence of excess H2, at temperatures 90–100 °C, which addresses the phenomena of permanent deactivation associated with the bi-functional Ru-catalysts based on sulfated supports [17,20,21,23,33,35,36]. 3.3.1 Discussion and plausible mechanism Based on the experimental observations and earlier reports in literature, it may be suggested that the hydrocyclization reaction on the bi-functional materials proceeds through a dual site mechanism whereupon levulinic acid adsorption/activation takes place on a hydrophilic/oxyphlic/acid site while H2 activation takes place on a redox site adjacent to it. Following hydrogenation, the intermediate 4-hydroxypentanoic acid (or γ-hydroxyvaleric acid) undergoes intramolecular esterification/cyclization producing γ-valerolactone (catalyzed by the strong acid sites) ( Scheme 3, case I) [23,33–35]. Further, in the situation of a high concentration of surface acid sites some of the levulinic acid molecules may remain strongly chemisorbed on the acid sites and, consequently may no longer be available to undergo hydrogenation (Scheme 3, case II), this behavior is indeed is reflected in terms of the reduced hydrogenation rates for catalysts/catalytic systems presenting higher surface acidity (e.g. Ru/mNbOPO4 and physical mixtures) and is in good agreement with the relatively high levulinic acid adsorption capacity of these materials (Supporting information, Table S1). In addition, in case of catalysts presenting a high surface acidity (e.g. 50%NbSi-COMp or mNbOPO4), 4-hydroxypentanoic acid or levulinic acid may remain strongly chemisorbed on catalyst acidic sites which may cause poisoning/fouling of the acidic sites. It is also worth highlighting that analysis of reaction mixtures (NMR, & HPLC) showed only the presence of 4-hydroxypentanoic acid and γ-valerolactone (Fig. S2, supporting information); pseudo levulinic acid, intermediate dehydration product (angelica lactones) and, over-hydrogenation products such as 2-methyltetrahydrofuran and pentane-1,4-diolcould not be detected. Furthermore, experiments in D2O and H2O proceeded at identical rates with no formation of H/D exchanged products in case of former, confirming the role of H2O as solely as a solvent. This indicates that under the investigated conditions the reaction proceeds via the kinetically favorable hydrogenation-esterification/cyclization/dehydration rote (Path A, Scheme 2), where hydrogenation was kinetically favored over the cyclization (i.e. 4-hydroxypentanoic acid cyclization as the rate limiting step). To summarize, a rationally designed bi-functional Ru catalyst presenting well dispersed Ru species decorated over SBA-15 modified with crystalline NbOPO4 (strong Brønsted acid) sites (i.e. Ru/20%NbSBA-15) presented exceptional activity and durability upon hydrocyclization of aqueous levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone. The bi-functional catalysts also outperformed the benchmark monofunctional as well as physically blended catalytic systems (in terms of initial reaction rates) while maintaining comparable γ-valerolactone selectivity (high dehydration activity) under the investigated conditions, confirming the advantage of bi-functional catalysts upon direct hydrocyclization of levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone (Table 3). Most importantly, unlike the bi-functional Ru catalysts incorporating unstable and reducible SO3H groups as the acidic sites, the acidic NbOPO4 phase of multifunctional Ru/20%NbSBA-15 catalysts were non-reducible and chemically robust under the harsh hydrothermal and reducing environments of the reaction [33–36]. In fact, it represents the first truly bi-functional, robust Ru-catalyst for energy efficient hydrogenation of levulinic acid reported till date (Table 4). Furthermore, the unique ability of the catalyst to work with low pressure H2 streams and any H2/feed ratio may enable development of a small-scale process for efficient γ-valerolactone production utilizing aqueous levulinic acid and renewable (low pressure) H2 from water electrolysis as feeds. Another advantage of the bi-functional catalysts reported here is the ability of the materials to work with aqueous levulinic acid streams (50 g/L), representing realistic levulinic acid feed obtained from biomass streams, a major improvement over the bi-functional Ru@DOWEX catalyst utilizing extremely diluted 0.23 g/L levulinic acid as a substrate [33]. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a Ru decorated NbOPO4 modified mesoporous SiO2 material (SBA-15) bearing bi-functional surface chemistry i.e. strongly Brønsted acidic NbOPO4 sites, and redox Ru sites was shown to exhibit exceptional activity and stability upon tandem hydrocyclization of aqueous levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone under mild reaction conditions (90–100 °C, 10 bar H2). The multifunctional catalyst incorporating the right balance of acid sites (viz. acid site concentration, B/L and M + S W ratio) outperformed the physically blended bi-functional catalysts comprising various supported Ru catalyst mixed with solid acids (NbOPO4/Amberlyst-15) as well the monofunctional Ru catalysts (e.g. Ru/SBA-15, Ru/MCM-41, Ru/NAC) in terms of activity and desired product selectivity. Most importantly, the Ru/20%NbSBA-15 catalyst incorporating well defined mesopores and crystalline NbOPO4 phase obtained via a post-synthetic modification of SBA-15 demonstrated remarkable stability in a fixed-bed reactor under continuous flow conditions, maintaining constant activity, and high γ-valerolactone selectivity during ca. 300 h time on stream operating at 10 bar and 90–100 °C and varying H2/levulinic acid flow rates. The exceptional catalytic performance and stability of the multifunctional Ru-catalyst was attributed to its unique acidic surface chemistry that stabilized the metallic Ru nanoparticles and also promoted cyclization/dehydration of intermediate 4-hydroxypentanoic acid over acidic NbOPO4 sites. Moreover, the acidic NbOPO4 sites of the bi-functional Ru/20%NbSBA-15 catalyst were robust and chemically stable under the experiential conditions, unlike the previously reported bi-functional Ru-catalysts incorporating unstable and reducible SO3H groups as the acidic sites [34–36]. coredata.dc:description: Herein, we demonstrate that surface acid-base properties have marked effect upon the performance (activity, selectivity and stability) of supported Ru catalysts upon tandem hydrocyclization (hydrogenation-dehydration) of aqueous levulinic acid. A mesoporous bi-functional Ru/NbOPO4/SBA-15 catalyst incorporating highly dispersed Ru sites and well balanced strong Brønsted acidic sites (optimum B/L and M+S/W ratio) was identified, which outperformed the benchmark monofuncational (Ru/SBA-15, Ru/MCM-41) and physically blended bi-functional catalysts (Ru catalysts mixed with acid co-catalysts e.g. NbOPO4/Amberlyst-15). Further, the catalyst also demonstrated remarkable stability in a fixed-bed reactor, maintaining steady activity and γ-valerolactone selectivity (72–86%) during ca. 300 h time on stream (10 bar, 90–100 °C), corroborating its industrial potential. The exceptional performance and durability of the bi-functional catalyst was attributed to the presence of well dispersed hydrothermally and chemically stable acid (NbOPO4) and redox (Ru) sites.
coredata.dc:title: Continuous hydrocyclization of aqueous levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone over bi-functional Ru/NbOPO4/SBA-15 catalyst under mild conditions
